title: No need to show Apache license on first startup
body:
For historical reasons we require all users to accept license of the IDE on first startup. The license has been updated to Apache one for 9.0 release. However I believe there is no need to show this license dialog/warning at all.

Removing it. Emptying the Java class (but keeping it around), removing reference in Unix launcher, as well as Windows one (but without rebuilding the binary). The license warning dialog is gone on all systems, once Windows launchers are rebuilt, the Java class `AcceptLicense` can be deleted as well.

title: Run two travis builds in parallel. Test signatures against latest release.
body: This should be a way speed-up the travis build by splitting it into independent parts. There can be as many as needed (just define new lines in `env` section). Each of the checks is controlled by an environment variable - can be `true` or not in each matrix configuration.

title: Signatures as of release 9.0
body:
I've just generated snapshots of APIs as of release 9.0 as advocated at [SignatureTest](http://wiki.netbeans.org/SignatureTest) to be done after each release:
```bash
incubator-netbeans$ git checkout release90 -f
incubator-netbeans$ ant clean build
incubator-netbeans$ ant gen-sigtests-release
incubator-netbeans$ git status --short | cut -c 4- | xargs zip /tmp/sig.zip
```
and I am updating the latest `master` with the content of the ZIP:
```bash
incubator-netbeans$ git checkout -f master 
incubator-netbeans$ unzip /tmp/sig.zip 
```
With this change we shall never regress our APIs with respect to 9.0 release.

title: #1065: No warnings when creating platform app
body:
Bugfix for [#1065](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-1065). With these changes I can create a NetBeans Platform Application, open project properties and the libraries report no errors on JDK-11 as well as JDK8.

The fix works only when using NetBeans from a binary. There are still some problems with `ant tryme` test. Hopefully not that important.

title: [NETBEANS-1074] Module Review php.apigen
Left/Right arrows are too generic for switching tabs.
body:
There is a (strange) registration for VK_LEFT and VK_RIGHT in OptionsPanel. I haven't found a way to trigger the registration from a Swing component - neither in the NetBeans IDE nor products build on top of it.

It makes little sense to bind such lowlevel arrow keys to such high-level task. Thus this change proposes Ctrl-Tab and Ctrl-Shift-Tab instead for switching the categories.

With this change I can easily switch categories in the IDE as well as eliminate the switching on left/right arrow press in a JFXPanel - an issue that motivated this change.

title: Initial implementation of @ActionState support
body:
Hi all !

I've decided to modernize implementation of actions in a project I am working on and found out that action support in OpenIDE lacks certain features. The most important  (for me) is the ability to combine `ContextAwareAction` with the `BooleanStateAction`: Because `BooleanStateAction` is a `SharedClassObject` descendant, it is both an ugly obsolete thing which should not be used at all and also the OpenIDE will fire some warnings into the log, because more instances of the same class is created - one per `Lookup` context.

This approach has another drawback: as the actions may appear in toplevel menu, the action code + potentially other classes may be loaded up front on application startup although the relevant editor for which the action(s) enable is not opened. 
This is not that important for my current project, but may be for modular/extensible applications and NetBeans IDE itself: the less code we preload the better is the initial/average performance.

Followin fellow colleague's advise, I've decided to adapt OpenIDE support a little. It got a lot more hairy than the initial need, and the implementation is uglier than I'd like, but these are the new features:

* OpenIDE can supply monitoring boolean/enum/stringifiable property of the context object object for their "enabled" state. Property listener attach/detach, only when someone observes the Action, weak listening, so Actions can be GCed, action creation for the proper context object - all that can be managed by OpenIDE support. No more needed to implement `ContextAwareInstance` for this use-case.

* (new !!) the same is supported for "checked" property: an action can be presented as checkbox or toggle button and corresponds to a property in the context object. The check/toggle status tracks the property - and you can even specify value for which the check is "on". General non-null and null values are supported, too.

* to support broader range of model objects, the above support which needs to listen on changes is not limited to `PropertyChangeListener` or `ChangeListener` event interfaces, but you can specify any listener class (and possibly even a trigger method) - a proxy listener will be created.

* because of possible weird combination of annotations, Action can enable on a certain context object, but grab its checked/toggled state from another context object's property.

* (new!) an Action can be optionally consulted for its `enabled` and `checked` state after the basic guards are evaluated by OpenIDE. Custom processing may happen, but the code will not load as long as the proper context object is not in place and until its guard property has the appropriate value: can avoid preloading, while still allows completely custom conditions.

All that allowed me to trash virtually all `implements ContextAwareAction` in my application and discard a lot of custom listening/enable/check code.

The above features made the `org.openide.actions.BooleanStateAction` rather obsolete - so I've deprecated it.

The entry point to all this is the `@ActionState` annotation; its Javadoc contains some examples. Less useful and hacked "examples" can be found in the `StatefulActionProcessorTest` test class.

Please do not hesitate to comment, supply patches to this patch, rewrite parts which are uglier than bearable.

[NETBEANS-369] Code-complete outputs unwanted newline characters
body:
The formatting change was introduced by the change to support reformatting
module declarations via mercurial changeset 4cbf6ecb92bc

http://hg.netbeans.org/main-golden/rev/4cbf6ecb92bc

The change in Reformatter.Pretty.visitCompilationUnit(CompilationUnitTree, Void)
was then conditionalized to only be applied to non-modules 
(git commit: 53ee08901ff0e4c2706b4050a54bc4672ab7994b)

https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/commit/53ee08901ff0e4c2706b4050a54bc4672ab7994b

That changeset left the regression for the general formatting in place
and removed the original use case for modules (for module declarations
the extra empty line is not introduced).

This changeset changes the situation back to the state before 4cbf6ecb92bc.

title: [NETBEANS-856] Remove last OASIS license references
body:
The catalog files were imported into the netbeans package because they
are missing from the maven central xml-resolver sources, but are part
of the binary on maven central.

The xml-commons-resolver-1.2.zip also contains the files:

http://archive.apache.org/dist/xerces/xml-commons/xml-commons-resolver-1.2.zip

so it is assumed they are part of the release.

So the netbeans binary is created by:

- fetching sources from maven central
- patching the source
- build new binary
- repackage the new binary:
  - add CRC reference to original library
  - merge grammar files from maven central binary

I just kept the master branch's file. Is this correct?

title: [NETBEANS-1083] Fix value replacement in POM editing
body:
#isRemovingAvailableLocked can only be true, if the scan of the remaining
tokens all report to be removable.

This is not the intention at the use site. The question, is whether
deletes in the current token are expected and so only the current token
needs to be checked.

title: Adds Version parsing to svn output.
body:
So comparing verion numbers would be based on numbers, not strings.
I.e. its now possible to determine if 1.2.2 and 1.2.123 have same MAJOR.MINOR version.

Fixes [NETBEANS-771](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-771).

NETBEANS-771 caused by version.indexOf("1.1") > -1 
it was fine for svn 1.9, but is broken since 1.10, as 1.10 is treated as 1.1. That is motivation behind actual parsing of string to version container.

title: [NETBEANS-691]: Corrected undo conversion of constructor to factory w…
body:
…hen refactoring in calling class

On undo-->redo-->undo after refactoring with 'Replace Constructor with factory' , second undo call was throwing CannotUndoException.

 UndoRedoManager.onSaveTasksEdit 'hasBeenDone' field became false after the redo call in this particular scenario.
So when second time undo is called, it throws CannotUndoException as hasBeenDone field is already false 

Jira Link:  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-691

title: NETBEANS-998: update display name when DelayedNode resolves it
body: In the branch for shadow, the name is localized through the DataNode, so the final value is seen immediately and can be fixed for the `DataShadowFilterNode`. But for "normal" nodes, the node may resolve the localized name later, in background and change it. It will fire events which the `DataShadowFilterNode` will happily forward, but `getDisplayName` need to delegate to the filer node so that the current value is returned to the caller.

title: Language Server Protocol client
body:
This is a crude prototype of a Language Server Protocol client for NetBeans.

It currently supports:
-diagnostics from the server
-go-to-declaration
-code completion

It uses the Eclipse LSP4J (https://github.com/eclipse/lsp4j) to handle the protocol and to provide the model for the messages (I used to have a custom implementation of the protocol, but it seemed wasteful to maintain that).

There are currently two ways to use a server from the IDE:
-a module provides bindings for a particular language, starts and registers a LS. I have a crude prototype of such a module using KotlinLanguageServer, but not good enough to that publish, yet.
-the user starts the LS manually somehow, and then binds the IDE to the running LS.

To see the client in action using the latter approach, the following can be used:
-clone https://github.com/fwcd/KotlinLanguageServer
--build it (gradle install)
--unpack build/distributions/kotlin-language-server-0.1.1.zip somewhere
-clone https://github.com/jlahoda/nb-lsp-helpers
--build it (ant jar in run-lsp)
--go to run-lsp/dist and run: "java -jar run-lsp.jar <path-to-the-kotlin-server>/bin/kotlin-language-server"
-run NetBeans, be sure there are no files opened in the editor, use the search feature in the top right corner, type "Connect", select "Connect to Language Server" action. Fill in your project's root (e.g. the path to the checked-out KotlinLanguageServer), port is 9965, extensions "kt". In a while the IDE should connect to a the LS. Then open a kt file (from the specified project), and the above features should work.

title: added extension-points to targets "compile", "jar", "release" and "nbm"
body:
Since Version "???" Ant has a feature called "extension point". The NetBeans build system can profit from this feature. Currently only one "legacy extension point" is available "netbeans-extra". This PR adds a "-pre"- and "-post" extension-points to the targets "compile", "jar", "release" and "nbm".

A blog post about my thoughts (in german):
https://blog.nigjo.de/netbeans/blog/2018/06/01/extension-points-in-ant/

title: [NETBEANS-853] Fix license info for entity definitions and DTDs
body:
The license information in the DTD was white-space corrected. The license info in
the *.ent (entity definitions) files was added after asking for clarification
on site-policy@w3.org.

Statement from Wendy Seltzer (Strategy Lead, World Wide Web Consortium (W3C)):

Hi Matthias,

W3C makes the DTD and entity files available under the Software License,
as you identified. They apparently incorporated some definitions from
ISO SGML, hence the reference to ISO 8879. I can't speak to ISO's terms,
but W3C does not assert any claims incompatible with Apache licensing.

Hope that helps,
--Wendy

This PR is opened against master, but I plan to cherry-pick it to release90 when reviewed.

title: [NETBEANS-862] Added auto-complete support for var keyword in JDK-11 Lambda Parameters
body:
Added Auto-complete support  for var keyword in Lambda parameter (JDK-11 or above). 

e.g.,(Suppose cursor is at '^' position. 
   IntBinaryOperator calc2 = (var x, ^ y ) -> x+y;

on ctl+space, below expected outcome should happen.
 IntBinaryOperator calc2 = (var x, var y ) -> x+y;

Test cases needs to be re-verified once nb-javac for jdk-11 is available.

Jira Link: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-862

title: [NETBEANS-837] Update winp to released 1.26 version and fix license
body:
winp is actively developed at: https://github.com/kohsuke/winp

The code in recent versions of winp looks very similar to the state after the
patching. The API is stable (checked with ``japi-compliance-checker``), so
the upgrade should be save.

Part of the license problem that the license integration code is not prepared
for files showing up at build time (winp was build from source) and not coming
from the normal download route.

_Update: I intend to push this patch also to release90 when reviewed, as the
issue was raised for the upcoming 9.0 release._

title: [NETBEANS-892] Fix lambda expr and multi catch rewrite issues
License cleanup part 2
body:
@emilianbold another set of cleanups for licenses/build issues. The individual commits hold
more information. The core info:

- maven-indexer was released as 6.0.0 and already contains the patch, so it can be dropped and we can switch to the maven artifact. The notice file was missing
- BIndex contains MIT licensed code and so needs an enhanced license and also notice info, which was extracted.

As before If not vetoed, I would cherry-pick this directly into release90 after review for master.
